    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Hawazi Daipi): Sir, yesterday I finished replying to questions on the Trim and Fit programme. Let me continue with what Mr Ng Ser Miang had called the gifted sports classes. Mr Ng would be glad to know that besides Parkview Primary School, there are 11 other primary schools, including Fuchun, Admiralty and Evergreen Primary schools, involved in this pilot scheme sponsored by the Singapore Sports Council. Anglican High School and Temasek Junior College have also started their sports classes. MOE's approach is to allow schools the autonomy to decide niche areas, including sports, depending on their needs and resources. However, I would like to clarify that these are not gifted sports classes. The Sports School, which is scheduled to open in 2004, will be in a better position than mainstream schools to look after the sports and academic needs of gifted young sports talents. It is for this reason that MOE supports the establishment of the Sports School by the Ministry of Community Development and Sports, which determines, among others, the Sports School's entry requirement.

    Let me now answer some specific queries from MPs. Dr Maliki suggested that the Ministry of Education conduct a study on the profile of the teenagers who had abortions and target our sexuality education at this group of teenagers. Our programme is targeted towards all pupils of different backgrounds and experience in sexuality matters. Our main focus is on education and character building. Our approach is directed at upstream measures and, hence, proactive in nature. We aim to impart to all pupils the necessary knowledge and inculcate a responsible attitude towards sexuality issues. MOE's Sexuality Education Programme was drawn up after studying successful programmes in both Western and Asian countries. This programme incorporates strategies to address the needs of teenagers who are at risk of engaging in sexual activities that might lead to teen pregnancies and abortions.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked if schools provide dedicated follow-up services to

Column: 1656

students suspended from school. As I mentioned yesterday, the school would only mete out disciplinary action like suspension, as a last resort, for the student to reflect on his misbehaviour. During the suspension, the pupil will be given school assignments to ensure that time is gainfully spent. Schools tap on professional MOE counsellors to work with pupils before and during the period of his suspension to deal with the root cause of his misbehaviour. Parents are also involved in this whole process to fully understand the purpose of suspension and to ensure proper supervision at home. When the pupil returns to school, a meeting would be held with him and the parents with the principal, to help the pupil integrate back into school life. The school would continue to provide counselling, when necessary.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong asked if our National Education programmes are kept up-to-date on current developments in national and global issues, like terrorism and the impending Iraq war. Yes, definitely. Current affairs provide very useful opportunities to raise national education issues for discussion. Within the classroom, History, Social Studies and General Paper lessons are examples of where this may be done. Outside the classroom, dialogue sessions with senior civil servants, annual pre-university seminars and various National Education talks are the usual forum to do so.

    Ms Braema Mathi expressed concern with the continued implementation of National Education and values education programmes when principals are rotated and changed. National Education and values education are key features of our education which are implemented in all schools. Furthermore, the system and processes for implementing these programmes are already in place in all our schools. Our principals and teachers will implement National Education and values programmes regardless of the schools that they are in.

    Mr Zainudin Nordin (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, even as a young boy, I sensed from my school environment that the arts

Column: 1657

subject is one which is least emphasised. It is the easiest to handle because faring well in it was really inconsequential, unless, of course, the student hopes to use the arts subject marks to pull up his or her cumulative results, then it becomes useful. On the other hand, parents are also not to be blamed. They respond to the environment and prepare their children to face the future where arts have little to contribute to. Perhaps this is what they feel. In times like this, my worry increases as support and resources for arts and culture are threatened. We have, however, demonstrated some commitments when funds are given to private arts schools like NAFA and LaSalle-SIA. However, the real issues remain: what is the position of arts in our local schools? Are qualified teachers teaching the subject, or has it been reduced to logistics and available manpower, ie, any teacher from any discipline that has an hour to spare will end up teaching the subject? Are we particular about standards? Is it still the first to be sacrificed each time the school is shorthanded?

    Mr Gan Kim Yong (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Sir, I am pleased that the Ministry of Education has taken several initiatives over the last three years to improve the pre-school education here. In December 2000, MOE announced the minimum qualification of kindergarten principals. In October the following year, the minimum qualification and composition of kindergarten teachers were defined. Earlier this year, a framework of kindergarten curriculum has been introduced and, finally, the MOE announced recently that the new Kindergarten Education Bill will be introduced in Parliament shortly.

    These are all aimed at ensuring quality pre-school education for our children. Some of us will remember the story of "Meng Mu San Chian". Meng Tze is a very famous Chinese scholar. His mother Meng Mu shifted house three times - not to upgrade from a 3-room flat to a 4-room flat, to a 5-room flat, and then to an Executive flat - but to give her son a better environment to study. This goes to show that the children's education is close to the hearts of parents. I

Column: 1658

therefore welcome the greater attention given to pre-school education here.

    Sir, I would like to make three points with regard to pre-school education. With the introduction of the new criteria and the framework of curriculum, we must have a system to monitor the progress of compliance, even though the curriculum is not compulsory, and I agree that it should not be made compulsory. We must be able to know which kindergarten has adopted it and which has not. The parents must also know, so that when they enrol their children, they can make informed choices. Therefore, can we consider some kind of accreditation system to give recognition to those who have adopted the system?

    Secondly, additional financial resources may need to be given to help the lower income families so that their children will not be denied pre-school education. Pre-school education is generally more expensive than formal education because there is limited Government funding. The lower income families may need help to keep their children in the kindergartens.

    Thirdly, I hope the introduction of the Kindergarten Education Bill will not imply greater rigidity. We must continue to encourage creativity and diversity. I hope the Government will continue with its light touch policy on education, more help and guidance, rather than control and regulation.

    Sir, although pre-school education is not compulsory, it has become very much a way of life for our younger families. With MOE placing greater emphasis on improving pre-school education, I have no doubt that our young ones will benefit from a better run pre-school system.

    Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong): Sir, I would like to applaud the Ministry for introducing a comprehensive framework to improve pre-school education in Singapore. Currently, pre-school education is not regulated by any authority. Although it is part of the childcare services, it may be subject to MCDS rules. The structure of pre-school education that exists

Column: 1659

today is very much geared towards preparing children for primary one. There is a lot of focus on teaching children to read, write and count, but very little on how to help them to acquire the kind of skills and thinking capabilities that are needed to help them deal with the increased complexities, both in our school system, as well as in life. However, Sir, to achieve the outcomes that are desired under this new pre-school education framework, we must have teachers with the quality and capabilities to deliver these new standards. This is where the new pre-school education teacher training framework and accreditation of teachers are very important. Teacher training will be a big challenge as many of the existing non-profit kindergartens do not have enough qualified teachers based on the new framework.

    Another challenge for most kindergartens would be how to provide kindergarten teachers with a challenging career path. If our teachers upgrade themselves, they will need better motivation and career path compared to what currently exists. Sir, with this revamp of the pre-school education system, there is clearly a need to look at the primary school syllabus as there is a linkage between the two. The Ministry has announced its intention to introduce single sessions and smaller classes for the lower primaries, and I also look forward to a revamp of the primary education syllabus so that there is a continuous flow from pre-school education to primary and to secondary schools.

    Let me now touch on parent perception. The research that was started by the Ministry on the pilot group indicated that most of the parents are happy with the new pre-school education change. I would like to ask that the Ministry continue to focus on reaching out to parents on the new pre-school education syllabus. My own experience tells me that there are still many parents who like the old rote learning method. Recently, one parent complained to me that the PCF

Column: 1660

kindergarten did not give enough Chinese spelling to her child, compared to the private kindergarten that her child was previously attending. So, if parents are geared towards one mindset, and the MOE wants to put pre-school education on another track, there will be a mismatch. One suggestion that I would like to make is for MOE to encourage those parents covered under the survey and who had found that the new pre-school education is better to speak up. In this way, other parents will also be more confident and will support the changes better.

    Sir, one other concern which parents may have is increased childcare fees. The improvements to teacher training and other teaching methodologies will increase the cost of childcare education. This may be passed on to parents. I hope that the Ministry can also address this point. The bottom 20-30% of households, for instance, is very sensitive to changes in prices of kindergarten education, and may pull out their children if prices go up. This would be detrimental to the very children whom we are trying to help.

    Sir, I also hope that the requirement to license kindergartens and all costs related thereto will not translate into higher business cost. I do ask that the Ministry exercise some restraint in imposing licence fees or other costs on kindergarten operators, as again I fear that this will get transferred to parents.

    Finally, Sir, I support the flexibility granted to kindergarten operators to develop their own curriculum based on the broad framework set by MOE. This is a step in the right direction and is in line with the need to provide greater diversity in pre-school education.

    In conclusion, Sir, I hope that we will achieve the outcomes desired by the Senior Minister of State, Mr Tharman, when he described the kind of pre-school children he wants to see - eager to learn, confident of themselves and willing to persevere, able to communicate with teachers and classmates.

    Mr Zainudin Nordin: Sir, our education reforms and training must create a globally competitive, creative, employable workforce. Our system must facilitate Singapore's transformation into a knowledge-based economy, and this system begins with the very young.

    A growing body of research has identified the complex interplay between the brain and what a child learns from his environment. And that the young immature brain is very open to early experiences, good or bad. The fact is that from the time of conception to the age of five, a child's brain develops at a faster pace than at any other time in his life.

    The National Association of Education of Young Children (NAEYC) in the USA believes that the children who have high-quality early childhood programmes "gain skills that are normally associated with greater brain development such as problem solving and language, mathematics and literacy skills." They also gain other competencies such as self-control, higher motivation for learning and social skills. Thus, it cannot be argued otherwise that pre-school education provides the foundation for learning throughout the child's life.

    Naturally, Sir, I am happy to see new initiatives such as the PSC grants and plans to uplift the pre-school standard. They are positive steps. However, I believe more needs to be done. I would encourage the approach to be more holistic - things like preparation for school, character development, discipline, the child's initiative, inquisitiveness, creativity and so on. My message is that the same amount of emphasis and importance that we give to formal education must also be given to pre-school education in Singapore.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, I am glad that since I last spoke on this topic in last year's Committee of Supply, the salary scales for teachers of special education (SPED) schools have been raised, although a gap still exists

Column: 1662

between mainstream and special education teachers. In fact, some special education teachers who teach children who are more difficult to handle are given monthly premium allowances. However, I understand that the whole issue of lack of career development and training opportunities of special education teachers still persists. In fact, there is a lack of trained special education teachers today.

    I do understand that SPED teachers are under the purview of NCSS, and not MOE. However, I would like to urge MOE, as the Ministry in charge of education, to spearhead and coordinate the training of these teachers who perhaps need even much more help, as they are handling children with special needs.

    In the case of secondment of mainstream teachers to SPED schools, I understand that MOE's policy is to limit the secondment to one or two terms of two years, so that these seconded teachers do not lose out in their career development as against their counterparts in the mainstream schools. This is indeed well intentioned but it, inadvertently, deprives SPED schools of a source of trained, dedicated teachers with a compassion for SPED students. Will it not be possible to accord such teachers equal opportunities to training and career development and advance, even as they are on secondment to the SPED schools?

    Another avenue by which SPED schools can have more access to the services of well-trained teachers from mainstream schools is to have a roster of postings of available and willing mainstream teachers to special schools and give them hardship allowances during this posting. This will facilitate the transfer and exchange of skills and knowledge, which will also benefit mainstream schools as the teachers become more conversant and compassionate to children with learning disabilities in their midst.

    Sir, I am also pleased to note that, in recent years, the inclusion of high functioning children with special needs into mainstream schools has received much higher understanding from MOE.

Column: 1663



    Since 1999, there has been one mainstream secondary school per cluster fitted with facilities to accommodate children with special needs. However, a recent study of inclusion of high functioning hearing-impaired students in mainstream schools shows that more has to be done at the operational level to alleviate some of the problems faced by the physically challenged students. For instance, in one case, a hearing-impaired student was punished at the school assembly for not doing what she was told. In fact, the real reason was that the teacher did not know that she could not hear the instructions clearly and thought she was acting up. A standard operating procedure could have been easily put in place to help ensure students with hearing impairment to hear the instructions, say, through a buddy system. More attention and thus resources are needed to improve the current structure and systems of integration for the special needs children.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong: Sir, there are about 20 special education schools today run by VWOs with funding support from the Government. There are numerous other organisations running special education services without funding support. However, there is a need to do more for special education. Sir, I should disclose my interest at this point that I am a director of Care Corner Limited, which is operating a learning clinic for children.

    I would like to request the Ministry to consider three areas: firstly, physical facilities for certain disabilities, eg, autism. There is a rather long waiting list for admission into special schools. I understand that the special school at Margaret Drive has a waiting list of about 200 and the average waiting time is about two years. We need to increase the capacity to meet the demand.

    Secondly, teacher training. I agree with Dr Amy Khor that this is an area that we should look into. I believe that one of the constraining factors is the critical shortage of qualified teachers for

Column: 1664

special education. Therefore, the existing teachers are all burnt out and this has led to even higher attrition. Part of the problem is the low remuneration level and the lack of a career path. The Ministry could look into this and see how we can help train more teachers in special education and provide them with a career path within the mainstream, so that they do not lose out.

    Thirdly, financial assistance. The real cost of providing education to children with special needs is very high, sometimes four to five times that for ordinary education. The actual cost varies depending on the type of disabilities. Some children may need individual specialists to help to cope with their learning difficulties. Few can afford this. The situation is compounded by the fact that it is quite common that one of the parents has to stop work to help take care of the child. Many of them are facing physical and emotional stress today. Sir, these parents need some help to cope with the situation. I hope that the Minister would consider providing additional assistance to the parents to help them keep their children in the special schools if needed.

    Sir, children are our asset and our hope for the future. They are a source of joy to our family life. A small number of them, unfortunately, need some extra help. If help is unavailable, they may drop out eventually and become a burden to the family, society and the nation. But if we can offer adequate and timely help, most of them may be able to contribute meaningfully to the society, and some of them may even make it back to the mainstream.

    Mrs Fang Ai Lian (Nominated Member): Sir, I too would like to join the chorus to ask for more support for special education. Not so long ago, we discussed about changes for upper secondary education to develop our best and brightest. So we also ought to discuss changes for special education in order to cater for the other end of the spectrum, which is the intellectually disabled including the autistic children.

    I too note that the numbers have increased. Perhaps the statistician would

Column: 1665

say that this is due to growing awareness. But the fact remains, as has been said by Mr Gan, that there is a queue waiting to be admitted to special schools.

    I think we have a wonderful education philosophy which is to accord free and compulsory education for all our young up to the age of 12. We should include these kids into this catchment as well. Already, quite a bit has been done. We have lowered the age of subsidy from 6 to 4, recognising the need to address this problem at an early age, so that these children can gain faster and fuller development. There is also a sum of $200,000 set aside to train special teachers, but it would take time. And that is the right philosophy. If we do not have the teachers, we cannot establish the schools as well.

    Admittedly, there is also the cost. It costs a lot more, $12,000 as opposed to $3,000. But if we look at other countries like the US and Australia, they, in fact, have specialist teachers on a one-to-one basis. And we should also aim to achieve this benchmark as well. Because, in the past, our expectations were not there, but this has changed. In the past, we might be contented to leave these children at home and allow siblings to look after them. This is not acceptable any more because we feel that these kids too can be developed. They too can become self-reliant and contribute to society as well.

    Sir, I urge that more should be done for special education.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam (Nominated Member): Sir, thank you for allowing me to speak on this topic.

    I support the views of Dr Khor, Mr Gan and I like what Mrs Fang Ai Lian has said that perhaps it is also time to step back, take a more macro view of the whole area of special education, as we have done for the JC curriculum, and look at it from all aspects to see what more can be done.

    For today, I would like to raise my concerns where the teachers are concerned and argue for the Ministry of

Column: 1666

Education to take them on board as their own teachers, rather than le them be managed by the voluntary welfare organisations. Currently, the teachers attend either Certificate in Special Education or Diploma in Special Education courses at the National Institute of Education. The NIE training processes do come under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Education through the Nanyang Technological University. The teachers, as already mentioned by Dr Khor, do not get salaries that are apple-for-apple comparisons with those in national schools. Teachers with Second Upper degrees earn about $500 less than those in MOE national schools. Those with 'A' level certificates earn about $300 less. While they may be teaching in smaller classes, the demands placed on these teachers are quite high. And many of these teachers are also burnt out, as has been mentioned, and the attrition rate is one in five.

    In the year 2002, 400 teachers with special education training were teaching 4,200 pupils, in a 1:10 teacher pupil ratio. In the year 2000, there were 476 teachers for 3,800 pupils, on a better ratio of 1:8 . So we do have a problem here where attrition is concerned, where morale is concerned, and I found it rather interesting that the special education teachers come under the Singapore Mercantile and Manual Workers Union. I hope the union stands by the aspirations of these teachers in the same way that the Singapore Teachers Union stands by teachers in national schools.

    As has been mentioned, upgrading for these teachers is very much dependent on the funds available with VWOs. VWOs, as we already know, do have a problem sometimes in raising sufficient funds. My question to the Ministry, barring historical reasons as to why these teachers do not come under the MOE is: is it possible to review this and bring them on board? After all, the primary objective is being fulfilled - that they are training our children and the training is based on pedagogical principles as directed by the Ministry of Education. This means that training programmes, career development, salaries, upgrading,

Column: 1667

promotions can all come under one body rather than, right now, be dispersed over many VWOs, which may have different systems.

    The Chairman: Ms Braema, wind up your speech, please.

    Ms Braema Mathiaparanam: Currently, the principals of these schools are not on any policy management studies programme. The teachers are not in the teachers' network, and I think these are great avenues for them to share information.

    The Chairman: Mr Ong Kian Min, take your two cuts together, please.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Sir, I recognise the need for schools to be upgraded. Many of our schools, designed and built in the previous era, cannot support the present demands. It is the amount of funds that schools have to raise that worries me. Among my own small circle of family and friends, I know of not less than four schools that are actively raising at least $3 million each through similar activities such as fun fairs, concerts and gala dinners.

    MOE pays for 95% of the infrastructure upgrading cost. If principals of PRIME schools were to adhere strictly to the set of standard specifications, they need to fork out only the balance 5%. But that alone could work out to be $800,000, based on the usual upgrading cost of $15 million. However, nowadays, there are more and more young and dynamic principals at the helm of schools. They have, and we should motivate and empower them to have, greater expectations of how an enriched learning environment can impact the holistic education of our children. They require more than these standard features and specifications to creatively nurture and develop the students under their charge. For example, the notion that learning is not static gives rise to a desire to have desks and chairs of various sizes and shapes placed in different configurations

Column: 1668

for different activities. The traditional classrooms, with just a teacher's desk, with rows of tables and chairs and a whiteboard, are not tenable any more. There should be storage cupboards, shelves, notice boards and other "props" in the classroom. These are deemed as extras and are not within standard specifications laid down by MOE. When we look further at computer or science laboratories, the standard items laid down a few years ago are not even required or useful any more. The following three principles, as proposed by the arts community, in favour of rules, should be considered.

    One, the rules should acknowledge the diversity of modern Singapore and, in fact, allow for the greatest possible expression of that diversity. That requires a climate of reciprocal tolerance, which means an acceptance of other's right to express and receive certain ideas and actions, and others accepting that we have the right not to be exposed against our will to one's expression of ideas and actions.

That exercise of choice is based on the principle of limited access and exposure, rather than total blanket bans or censors over any questionable material. A regulatory system which bans nothing, but allows everything, through regulating the distribution and access, should be set up. The model should be based on a system of rating, zoning and belting. Rating classifies works, like films, books, plays, magazines, etc, according to their content, and imposes age limit, like the current film ratings that we have. Under this system, no work is banned outright.

    Zoning classifies geographical areas when works of certain ratings are restricted to certain parts of the city or certain areas within a bookshop, video shop or retail shop. Belting classifies time period, like on television or radio or types of media, such as newspapers or restrictive circulation like magazines, according to reach, imposing stricter limits on time period and media with greater reach according to the rating.     This was why I decided last year to convene the Censorship Review Committee (CRC) to seek their views on what we should do to bring our censorship system up-to-date. They have had 15 focus group discussions and talked to more than 300 people and received many more representations from the public at large. They have also taken in the views expressed in articles and commentaries carried by the media, and commissioned a survey to obtain direct public feedback on key censorship issues.

Mr Steve Chia has raised the concept of rating, zoning and belting. This is not new. We do this now in terms of film classifications, as he has indicated, in terms of shifting certain programmes onto late night television or allowing certain types of programmes only on paid television and not free-to-air television, and so forth.

of our society. So, in considering this point that Mr Chia advocates, we must ask ourselves this question whether, and to what extent, we want to shift the boundaries on pornography, and why? Or, we should not approach it as a choice for choice's sake.

    Sir, in responding to the CRC report, I will be guided by a number of basic considerations. Firstly, we must develop our own approach. We are a young society, raised on traditional values and seeking to fit into a global world. We are also multi-religious, multi-racial, multi-cultural. We therefore cannot simply follow foreign norms or import ideas from societies that are culturally different from us. It simply would not work. We must develop our own formula and base these on sound and clear principles.

    Secondly, we must look at the issues from all sides. This is almost axiomatic. But if we do not see or try to see the concerns of others, there is no reason why they should see our concerns. And if any one insists on absolute freedom for himself, then he denies all others any freedom at all. So, if we hope to find workable ways to accommodate our different views and values, we must be prepared for some give and take, and to take progress one step at a time.

    Thirdly, we should aim to move at a pace that the society, as a whole, can accommodate. We have not dramatically changed our approach to censorship over the last 10 years, and yet anyone who has lived during that period will recognise that we have eased up in many areas. Friends who have come to visit us after a long while feel that it is different now, and yet acceptance of our current censorship norms is still very high. This means that we have managed to find a workable balance, that is, the tension between being too inflexible and changing too quickly, and we should continue to work for such a balance.

    Finally, Sir, we must recognise that decisions eventually have to be taken and then we have to move on. As the CRC process demonstrates, the views of the public are widely canvassed when developing censorship policies. Likewise, we have many advisory and review and appeal committees. The public inputs are obtained to guide the implementation of censorship rules. But in the final analysis, the Government, as elected leaders,

this e-mail from Mr Saw Ken Wye, Chairman of Singapore IT Federation. He thanked me for my speech and the message which he agreed. Column: 1742

desk-top computers, and it is now betting on its Centrino chip to be in most laptop computers. It hopes that its "Intel inside" act I could be followed by a "Centrino inside" act II.

providers and more than 240 wireless LAN hotspots throughout Singapore.

    Let me now reply to Mr Steve Chia's cut on the subject of junk e-mails, commonly called e-mail spamming. There are really two parts to this issue. First, can we prosecute e-mail spammers? Yes, we can. E-mail spammers can be prosecuted if the e-mail spam is serious enough as to cause a degradation of the computer system and resulting in disruption of service. Victims can report to the Police who can pursue it under the Computer Misuse Act. Members may remember - I think it was two years ago - there was such a case when someone was prosecuted for bombarding HDB's computer department with something like 7,500 junk mails over a period of 21/2 hours. But the act of sending unsolicited email is itself not illegal. When used appropriately, it is a very legitimate form of marketing.

    The second aspect: is the unauthorised selling of email addresses illegal in Singapore? We do have sectoral legislation that contains provisions to protect an individual's personal information and that will include his or her email addresses. For example, under the Banking Act, banks are not allowed to sell the email addresses of their customers. Likewise, under the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics Act, it would be illegal for hospitals and clinics to pass on the email addresses of their patients to a third party.

    However, if a company has collated email addresses from the Internet or from the Singapore Directory, repackage it and resell the information to interested marketers, the marketers are basically buying already public information, which they could otherwise obtain free of charge.

    Just last week, Minister David Lim received an unsolicited email from a company promoting a software package which it claims can, and I quote, "harvest hundreds of thousands of email addresses within seconds", and the word used is "harvest". And this is the type of spider which the industry talks about.

    Sir, email spamming is a global phenomenon. We are not alone. It can be a

Column: 1746

nuisance but overall the extent of spamming here is still relatively low. How do other countries respond to it? Is there any good model for us to follow? Unfortunately, the answer is no.

    Is legislation effective? The US experience is that anti-spam laws are not effective. The US has state laws against spamming, some dating back several years. But despite the law, successful suits against spammers are rare and the extent of spamming has not gone down. In fact, it has gone up. Australia too has concluded, after a study in August last year, that legislation alone will not be effective in curbing spams.

    One reason why spams are difficult to eradicate is that the majority of them originate from overseas. Anti-spam laws, even if enacted, do not have effective jurisdiction against spammers who are based overseas. We have just to adopt a practical approach, comprising (a) industry self-regulation; and (b) consumer education. This approach takes into account and balances the legitimate interests of businesses and consumers.

    Under this approach, our Internet Service Providers (ISPs) have all adopted best practices to counter spams originating from their subscribers. Each ISP has a policy of suspending the email account of its own customers. Users should also take some personal responsibility to safeguard their email information, just as we all do for our other personal particulars, such as telephone numbers and residential addresses. Some simple tips I would offer include the following: do not freely disclose your email address; only disclose your email address to organisations or websites that practise personal data protection principles; and of course, install anti-virus software. As a parent, I constantly remind my daughters about these tips. And here, my worry goes beyond just the nuisance of spamming.

    In short, Sir, we cannot eradicate spamming, just as we cannot avoid catching the flu occasionally. But we can reduce the nuisance. And IDA will step up its public education programmes on how

Column: 1747

email users can better protect themselves against spams.

have to be creative in the promotion efforts. So, last month we launched the Library Ambassador programme to promote reading and learning. create something different and of value to Singaporeans.

to use the other languages, unless we are quite certain that the targeted audience is already comfortable with English.

up Mandarin, English and Bahasa. But even then, the school environment was largely Hokkien-speaking. I recall that we did not take languages too seriously, except to pass school examinations. At that time, we did not have compulsory PSLE examinations.

    This afternoon, while we focus on our domestic issues, let us not lose sight of the turmoil in the international arena. We must not take safe harbour for granted, and must continuously work towards maintaining national peace and harmony.

    Sir, I would like to also acknowledge the 98 cuts that MCDS received - the most among all the Ministries.     Sir, MCDS' vision is for Singapore to be a cohesive and resilient society. However, unlike Ministries that directly deliver the end outcomes, such as a good education or health system, MCDS primarily plays the role of facilitator, enabler and catalyst. We encourage and enable the individual to show resilience, the family

Column: 1782

to show care and support, and the community to show inter-group understanding and interaction. We may be the cheerleaders, and sometimes even the coach or the physiotherapist, but we are not the players. The players are each and every Singaporean.

    A cohesive society is one that displays unity in diversity. We want to ensure we have strong social networks amongst Singaporeans.

    Players matter most. That is why they are valued more than coaches or physiotherapists. A soccer team cannot perform at its best on the pitch, if the players do not get along off-pitch, whether because they let their different backgrounds come in the way, or because of other reasons, such as stolen girlfriends or flying boots. In the same way, Singapore's ability to cope with tough times would also be affected, if Singaporeans from various segments of society are not united.

    Our society has also been likened to a dish of rojak - many different pieces, each with its own distinctive feel and flavour, with the prawn paste binding them together and enhancing their taste. The test of a good rojak is in the paste. A cohesive society is like a good dish of rojak, with thick prawn paste being the inter-group understanding, the interaction and cooperation, as well as the shared values and aspirations that bind the various ethnic groups together. Our challenge is to ensure that we have the right paste, or the appropriate connectors that can only be developed through enlarging our common space.

    Social cohesion is about building social capital. Social capital refers to the social trust, norms and networks that people can draw upon for mutual benefit. In other words, people getting together and growing comfortable with one another, eg, through dialogues and networking, as well as working and interacting on common projects. In this manner, we build social capital and not allow social exclusion to take place. If any group feels that it does not belong, and feels excluded, then our rich social tapestry is at risk.

Column: 1783



    But, as Mr Charles Chong has said, social cohesion must go beyond racial and religious harmony, and includes collaboration between various groups, eg, between religious and secular groups, between the rich and the poor, between the young and the old, and between citizens and foreigners. We want to create opportunities for such groups to interact in all aspects of life, such as through the arts, culture, sports and recreational activities.

    A cohesive society should also go beyond mere talk to action. Volunteerism, philanthropy and mutual self-help groups can enable people to connect, cooperate and build bridges across social divides. These activities enable social groups to interact and affirm common values, such as helping the less fortunate. Common values that all groups can uphold are a vital dimension of the common space. We also want more of the support groups that Miss Penny Low talked about.

    Sir, it is widely believed that one test for social cohesion in Singapore is the war on Iraq, which started this morning. Both Mayor Zainul and Mayor Heng have touched upon this. As reported in the newspapers, there is some feeling against the war, and this feeling cuts across racial and religious groups, even though there is strong support for the Government's stand as rational and in Singapore's interest. Such variations in views are inevitable. They are found even in the US. Whatever our personal views, I am confident that we will maintain our shared perspectives as Singaporeans. We have passed previous tests, and I am confident we will pass this one.

    Whilst a cohesive society is one that displays unity in diversity, a resilient society is one that shows unity in adversity. Singapore has had a relatively smooth ride, although a carefully managed one, in the past 25 years. But now we are entering into a much more competitive, volatile and uncertain environment, both economically as well as geo-politically. The ability to recover

Column: 1784

quickly from setbacks, whether from the loss of a job, of loved ones, or from something like the shock of the Jemaah Islamiyah arrests, these are tests of our resilience.

    We must be able to bounce back from misfortune and cope positively with challenges. In fact, we must tackle challenges head-on. To enable this, MCDS promotes individual resilience, family resilience and community resilience.

    At the individual level, MCDS promotes personal responsibility and self-reliance. We provide a basic social safety net to look after the well-being of the socially disadvantaged. This net will help them build up their self-esteem, so that they can get back on their feet as much as possible. A good example of individual resilience is the story of Elim Chew, highlighted in the newspapers last week. She left school early, but continued her education in the school of hard knocks, and turned out as an extremely successful streetwear retailer. A firm believer in an attitude of gratitude, she even gives half her income to community causes.

    At the family level, we help create a social environment that is conducive to having children and raising families. We help facilitate programmes that strengthen families, so that they can continue to be the first line of care and support for the individual. The State can provide financial support to needy individuals, but it can never replace the emotional care and social support that only family members can give. A good example of family resilience is the story of Kenny Goh. His company, Ken-Air, may have collapsed, but his family ties have strengthened.

    At the community level, we promote the principle of "Many Helping Hands" and enable communities to solve their problems together. The haves should help bridge the social divide by helping the have-nots. More than that, there should be more collaboration between and within groups. Community activities nurture human bonds, mutual support and social networks, which neither the

Column: 1785

State nor the market can provide. A good example of community resilience is the Seniors Befrienders programme run by the Lions Befrienders Service Association. Quite a number of the befrienders, who provide meal delivery and errand running, among other things, are elderly themselves. In fact, 23 befrienders are 80 years old or older.

Nine out of 10 Singaporeans were satisfied with race and religious group relations in Singapore. Hence, I said that my Ministry would be conducting another survey in 2002, to see if the views have changed.

76% in 2002. In fact, a much higher proportion of Malays indicated that they have close friends of another race, from 71% in 2001 to 86% in 2002.

    Sir, these findings speak well of the current racial and religious group relations. It suggests that there is a certain amount of social resilience among Singaporeans in general, a social resilience that provides a sound foundation for safeguarding and enhancing racial and religious group relations in Singapore, despite shocks, such as terrorism.

    However, one note of concern is that, unlike 2001, in 2002 we found that only six out of 10 Singaporeans with tertiary education were satisfied with current race and religious group relations. This might be due to a greater sensitivity to the global terrorist threat, as well as perhaps increasing expectations of what constitute good racial and religious group relations.

    Sir, one of the basic characteristics of Singaporean life is the presence of, and the continued need to enhance our common space. Our common space reflects what makes us uniquely Singaporean, while embracing the diverse cultures and faiths that we come from.

    The presence of the common space allows for the diversity to flourish primarily because what brings a diverse people to the common space are the values and aspirations that define us all as Singaporeans. Without this shared aspiration and the common values that define us, there will be no Singapore. But how the common space grows depends largely on how the different communities see the value in preserving a uniquely Singaporean identity. Hence, we need to continuously encourage the building of ties across all groups, in order to demonstrate this value to all Singaporeans.

    Most of us would have experienced the idea of being in a common space one way or the other as part of living in Singapore and being Singaporean at heart. Let me cite some everyday examples.

    Sports is a universal activity and passion for Singaporeans, regardless of age, gender, race and religion. During the last World Cup finals, big screens were set up at a few public areas, and even hospitals, for people to enjoy the match together. You could even find crowds sitting or standing outside shops selling television sets, watching soccer together. And every time a goal was scored, they would cheer together, and every time the referee made a bad call, they would jeer him together.

    There are also not many countries where you can find temples, mosques and churches peacefully co-existing next to one another. Just look at our Chinatown, Little India or Geylang East. We know of several places of worship in Singapore built with generous donations from all Singaporeans, regardless of race or religion. For example, Dr Theyvendran, who oversaw the renovation of the Sri Senpaga Vinayagar Temple in Ceylon Road, told me that the temple received donations from Muslims, and involved Chinese architects in its design.

    Sir, we respect diversity within the common space, so that all can be comfortable and feel at home in it. Diversity goes beyond race and religion. The common space includes diverse groups, with different interests and needs. Examples include environmentalists, arts groups and sports enthusiasts. In other words, it is a space that all Singaporeans have a stake in, no matter what we are and what our interests are. Common space is underpinned by our shared values, such as our belief in nurturing strong families, meritocracy, multi-racialism and a corrupt-free Government.

    Sir, some are concerned that by enlarging the common space, our private values and ways of life will be threatened. It is not a zero-sum game. While we have our private needs and preferences, we can accommodate and appreciate others who are different within

Column: 1788

the common space. What we do in our private space should not make it harder to mingle and understand others outside of our belief systems. Cultural and religious values, when practised in the spirit intended, should help to enrich and enlarge the common space.

    Sir, as Mr Charles Chong and Mr Zainul Abidin have pointed out, as a society, we need to find ways to meaningfully engage one another, negotiate our differences and move forward. The Grassroots Organisations (GROs), Inter-Racial Confidence Circles (IRCCs) and Harmony Circles are some of these platforms.

    IRCCs and Harmony Circles are avenues to expand the common space. The IRCCs are in a good position to help Singaporeans make sense of events that affect their lives. The IRCCs comprise a diverse group of national leaders from the local community. Currently, the members comprise 23% Malays and 16% are Indians. Half are people from outside the grassroots network, including community, school and religious leaders.

    Through the IRCCs, community and religious leaders form friendships and better understand one another. Armed with a good understanding of other communities as well as their own communities, the IRCC members are in a better position to help their own communities and followers navigate through sensitive or difficult issues.

    The friendships and understanding built up will also help manage the ground reactions during times of crisis. While some people doubt the value of visiting religious places of worship, IRCC members told me that this is like visiting someone in his own home. It really breaks the ice among the members.

    IRCCs also add value to grassroots organisations by giving suggestions on how their activities can be more inclusive. For example, avoiding evening activities on Thursday nights, as Muslims tend to congregate in mosques at those times for extended prayers. And this culminates with the Friday afternoon

Column: 1789

prayer session. Many Hindus, for example, visit the temple on Friday evenings, just as many Christians go to church on Sunday mornings. Besides playing this advisory role, IRCCs also reach out to promote cross-cultural activities that attract all races and religions and engage in public education.

    To further support such bottom-up community initiatives, my Ministry will give more than $80,000 for four community projects under the pilot phase for the Community Harmony Grants Scheme. Let me give two examples of the approved projects.

    The Inter-Religious Organisation will develop an inter-faith manual to guide community and grassroots groups who wish to organise more inclusive community events and activities that would cater to the needs of Singaporeans of various faiths.

    The Joint Social Service Centre in Central Singapore CDC will be starting a course for frontline staff, such as nurses and social workers, to enable them to better appreciate ethnic differences and serve their clients of different races more effectively.

    These are just two examples. We would, of course, be very happy to hear new ideas from any Member of Parliament or member of the public on activities that can bring about better inter-group understanding.

    Apart from facilitating inter-racial and inter-religious activities, the Government has also worked with religious groups to reaffirm Singapore's commitment to fundamental principles that have held Singapore together as a multi-religious society.

    The Minister of State for Community Development and Sports, Mr Chan Soo Sen, has been leading this effort. His working committee has held many dialogues with main religious groups and achieved a consensus on the Declaration on Religious Harmony. He will be ready to share about the Declaration soon.

    Sir, one concrete way of strengthening ties and bonds in our society and bridging social divides is to promote volunteerism and philanthropy. Philanthropy refers to the giving of money and resources for charitable purposes. It comes from the Greek word for "love for mankind". This sense of giving back to the community cuts across all boundaries, be it class, age, gender, race or religion.

    Sir, we have a strong charitable culture in Singapore. Foundations, clan associations and religious and community groups, work tirelessly to raise funds for various causes. Most people would expect charitable giving to fall in bad times. But the numbers show that even in bad times, the haves are doing more to help the have-nots. Donations to Institutions of Public Character rose every year from $157 million in 1995 to $381 million in 2001, despite the financial crisis

Column: 1791

in 1997 and the economic downturn in 2001. Similarly, our national volunteerism rate increased from 9.3% in 2000 to 14.9% last year.

    We do not have the 2002 figures yet, but recent fund-raisers such as the President's Challenge and the Ren Ci Hospital Charity Show have received overwhelming public support. The donations to the President's Challenge increased 50% from $4.1 million in 2001 to $6.3 million in 2002. The Community Chest, which raised $37 million in FY 2001, expects to meet its fund-raising target of $40 million in FY 2002. All this shows that we are indeed a caring, cohesive and compassionate society.

    Philanthropic activities in Singapore are not new. But we need more modern-day versions of Lee Kong Chian, Govindasamy Pillai, CJP Paglar and Mohammed Eunos Bin Abdullah - people who had a passion and did good for the community. We should preserve the spirit of philanthropy and broaden its base. Philanthropy is about "giving back" to society. It provides an important channel for the more successful to help others and to better our society. It is an important bridge, nurturing people in a world of increasing income inequality. Besides bringing people together, philanthropic activities are critical in complementing the Government in providing financial support for social causes. There is room for more philanthropists in Singapore. So I fully agree with Mr Charles Chong that more needs to be done to promote philanthropy in Singapore as a way of bridging the income divide.

    An excellent example of a modern-day philanthropic organisation in Singapore is the Tsao Foundation. It is guided by the vision of their founder, Mrs Tsao Ng Yu Shun, who was 86 years young when it was first chartered in 1993. She wanted to do something about the challenges of growing old. Tsao Foundation became one of the few philanthropic organisations in Asia that provides services rather than grants. The Foundation carries out a

Column: 1792

wide range of programmes, including a community-based healthcare programme, which runs a domiciliary medical clinic service, and a community care management service.

    Hence, my Ministry will provide more resources to the National Volunteer Centre to promote philanthropy. The National Volunteer Centre currently promotes volunteerism as a way of life. Promoting philanthropy has good synergy with volunteerism, as both call on Singaporeans to give of their time, talent and resources, to make a difference to the community.

    Sir, as I mentioned earlier, Singaporeans donate generously. They do so as they trust and are confident that the charities will do the right thing. We should not take this trust for granted. Charities should be prepared to show that the donations are spent wisely, and go towards programmes that make a difference.

    The challenges we face go beyond encouraging charity and keeping faith with the donors. Philanthropy has to be increasingly strategic, and directed at emerging social needs. Money raised should be invested for good results. Some social problems need to be tackled via the root causes. For those who can be helped to help themselves, we should empower them, rather than provide a crutch. For those who need lifelong support, there must be a safety net to protect them. We need to channel our passion and resources strategically to tackle the social challenges that we face.

    In developed countries, donors, especially rich philanthropists and foundations, are moving towards a model of social investment. They want to be involved in enterprising, outcome-driven programmes. They donate funds, share expertise with non-profit agencies, and take an interest in the programmes. For example, the Robin Hood Foundation was set up by an investment banker to raise funds and partner organisations to fight poverty in New York. Programmes are regularly reviewed for results, and

Column: 1793

the foundation also sources for expertise to help programmes do better.

    We need to find new ways of getting the best social value from the charity dollar. We need to find ways of encouraging new philanthropists, who expect and want greater involvement for the funds they donate, to come to the fore. Our infrastructure has to support the growth of more foundations and philanthropists, and enable our charities to run the distance. Corporations can add value by partnering non-profit organisations in their programmes, and exercise social responsibility. They will also infuse corporate expertise into the non-profit sector.

    Sir, another concrete example of community self-help is social entrepreneurship. Social entrepreneurship is about bringing business practices or innovation to solve social problems.

    One example is the recently-established Food from the Heart programme, which delivers unsold bread from bakeries across the island to charity homes. It was initiated by a couple, who used their logistics expertise and implemented a mobile tracking system. The system, accessed by handphones, coordinates the times and routes volunteers take to transport bread and pastries to some 35 homes. A social enterprise is essentially a business with a social mission, not merely commercial objectives.

    Many Voluntary Welfare Organisations like MINDS, Teen Challenge and the Singapore Association of the Visually Handicapped also have humble commercial activities or what may be termed as social enterprises.

    Social enterprises are becoming more sophisticated. One example is the Industrial Services and Cooperative Society, commonly known as ISCOS, set up in 1989, to help discharged inmates re-integrate into society through work rehabilitation. It promotes self-esteem and economic independence by developing businesses to provide employment opportunities. ISCOS is financially self-sufficient, and profitable with healthy

Column: 1794

revenue. Another example is the Development of Economy for Women Credit Cooperative Ltd, or DEW, which has assisted 1,500 women since 1981 to save together regularly and lend to one another from the savings at a reasonable rate of interest.
